PostValue.explanation: This post is a useful, pragmatic synthesis for advocacy: it collects economic arguments and references showing personal cost savings, job creation in alternative proteins, and very large indirect savings (healthcare, climate, ecosystem services). For the EA/rationalist community it is moderately important — not foundational to core longtermist priorities (e.g. AI x‑risk), but quite useful for strategy, coalition‑building, and policy advocacy around food systems and public health. For general humanity the stakes described are large (trillions in potential savings, lives and emissions), so the topic is significant; however the post is a secondary synthesis rather than primary evidence or a novel theory, and its impact depends on the robustness of cited studies and real‑world political uptake. Overall it’s a practical, moderately high‑value contribution to persuasion and policy discussion, but not a paradigm‑shifting or foundational paper.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Over-aggregation and overstated certainty around “trillions” — The post aggregates a wide range of studies (different countries, methodologies, definitions, years) into a single headline claim without clarifying heterogeneity, uncertainty, or possible double‑counting (e.g. counting health + pollution + climate savings that overlap). Actionable fix: add a short methodological caveat and either (a) present a few consistent scenario estimates (define scope, year, discounting) or (b) avoid a single large-sum headline and instead show a range and why estimates differ. Consider adding a one-paragraph appendix or callout summarising key methodological differences in the major reports you cite. 

2) Jobs claims risk being misleading because they ignore net and distributional effects — Many cited reports give gross job figures or optimistic scenarios; the post doesn’t address job displacement, automation, regional impacts, or transition costs for workers and communities. Actionable fix: distinguish clearly between gross vs net job estimates, call out likely short-term losses in some regions/sectors, and cite (or at least acknowledge) literature on labour reallocation and automation in food systems. Recommend including recommended policy responses (retraining, wage insurance, community transition funds) so claims about political palatability are credible. 

3) Political and behavioural feasibility is underdeveloped — The post assumes large dietary shifts are achievable and cost‑saving without engaging with uptake barriers (taste/culture, food access, demand elasticity), timeline uncertainties, or potential rebound effects (e.g. cheaper diets increasing caloric consumption). Actionable fix: add a short section on implementation pathways and realistic adoption scenarios (e.g. 10–30 years), note where savings accrue (consumer vs public budgets), and flag the most plausible policy levers that would produce the economic benefits you describe. This will make the piece more persuasive to politicians and less vulnerable to obvious counterarguments.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback flags three substantive, high-impact weaknesses: over-aggregation/overstated certainty of the ‘trillions’ headline, misleading job figures (gross vs net and distributional impacts), and underdeveloped feasibility/behavioral issues. Each point is accurate, actionable, and would materially improve credibility without forcing a long rewrite (a short caveat, clarified phrasing, and a brief implementation/transition note suffice). Addressing these would prevent obvious objections and reduce risk of embarrassing overclaims; it isn’t catastrophic to the post’s core claim but is critical for persuasive accuracy.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I cannot identify a widely known EA/rationalist author going by "Björn 🔹" (or that exact handle) in my training data (cutoff June 2024). The name is common and the diamond emoji suggests a username/pseudonym; there are no clear major publications, talks, or community leadership attributed to that specific handle. If you can share a link, more context, or other names/works, I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Strengths: The post has a clear thesis, logical structure with headings (consumer, direct, indirect benefits), frequent citations, and a concrete policy-oriented takeaway — making it easy to follow and persuasive for its audience. Weaknesses: It is somewhat list-heavy and repetitive in places, sometimes aggregates large figures without clarifying methods or assumptions, and a few claims could use tighter synthesis or signposting (e.g., reconciling differing estimates and acknowledging methodological caveats). A slightly more concise summary of the key numbers and clearer treatment of counterarguments would make it exceptional.

PostNovelty.explanation: This post is primarily a synthesis of existing studies and policy arguments rather than original research or a new theoretical claim. EA readers and animal-advocacy specialists are likely already familiar with the core points — cost savings from plant-based diets, large externalities from animal agriculture, and job-potential in alternative proteins — so the novelty for that audience is low. For the general public the piece is moderately novel: aggregating many recent reports into concrete, large-scale dollar and job estimates (trillions in externalities, tens of millions of jobs, specific per-country savings) can be striking and not widely known, though the basic ideas have been circulating in mainstream media and policy debates.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: Clear, audience-aware framing and a logically coherent case (consumer savings, direct job creation, and large indirect externality savings), supported by a range of studies including peer-reviewed articles and major reports. Weaknesses: The argument relies heavily on scenario-based modeling with heterogeneous methods and assumptions (risking optimistic or incomparable estimates), under-addresses transition costs, regional heterogeneity, distributional impacts, and potential sectoral job losses, and sometimes leans on NGO/consultancy reports or preprints without deeper critique. Overall the post provides reasonable, but not definitive, support: persuasive as a policy-advocacy case, but lacking the rigorous counterfactual and sensitivity analysis needed to claim the very large aggregate savings as settled fact.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most of the post’s major empirical claims are supported by the cited studies and reports. Key empirical figures (JAMA trial ~16% grocery savings; Lancet Planetary Health 2021: 22–34% cheaper in high/upper‑middle income countries; Nature Food 2023: up to $7.3 trillion in production‑related externality savings; PNAS 2016: $1–31 trillion; Eurogroup for Animals / Impact Institute: ~€1.5T+€1.45T ≈ €3T external costs; Systemiq 2025: €65bn and up to 250k jobs for a high‑ambition Germany scenario; Faunalytics 2025: ~70k jobs and ≈$224B GDP in an optimistic US scenario; GINA/ClimateWorks 2023: up to 83M jobs and large economic value by 2050; UK analyses/Bryant/OHE medRxiv: NHS savings estimates) are all traceable to reputable reports or peer‑reviewed papers. However, most large economic “savings” and job‑creation numbers are scenario‑dependent (often “high‑ambition” or full‑adoption scenarios) and rest on modelling assumptions; some cost studies (e.g., German MDPI, VeChi/affiliated work) show mixed results where vegetarian—not always vegan—is cheapest, or that some vegan variants can cost more (high‑protein/ultra‑processed options). A few reports are commissioned or funded by advocacy groups (possible conflicts-of-interest) and many policy‑relevant projections assume strong policy/intervention and behavioural change. Overall: accurate and well‑sourced, but numbers should be presented with their scenario/assumption caveats.
sources: JAMA Network Open (Kahleova et al.), 2023 — 'Vegan Diet and Food Costs Among Adults With Overweight' (secondary analysis showing ~16% daily food cost reduction). PMC article: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10481244/ (JAMA Netw Open, 2023).

The Lancet Planetary Health, 2021 — 'The global and regional costs of healthy and sustainable dietary patterns: a modelling study' (findings: high/upper‑middle income countries: some healthy vegetarian/vegan patterns 22–34% cheaper). https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanplh/article/PIIS2542-5196(21)00251-5/fulltext

Nature Food (Lucas et al.), 2023 — 'Low‑carbon diets can reduce global ecological and health costs' (estimates up to $7.3 trillion savings). PubMed/PMC: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37188875/ (Nat Food 2023).

Springmann et al., PNAS, 2016 — 'Analysis and valuation of the health and climate change co‑benefits of dietary change' (monetized benefits estimate: US$1–31 trillion by 2050). https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.1523119113

FAO (State of Food Security / related analyses), 2020 — estimates of diet‑related health costs (~US$1.3 trillion by 2030) and avoided deaths under healthy/vegan scenarios (e.g., ~13.7 million avoidable deaths for vegan scenario in 2030). FAO reports and open knowledge pages (2020). https://openknowledge.fao.org/

Eurogroup for Animals / Impact Institute, 2023 — 'External costs of animal sourced foods in the EU' (reporting ~€1.5T production and ~€1.45T consumption externalities — ≈€3T total). https://www.eurogroupforanimals.org/library/external-costs-animal-sourced-foods-eu
Nature Food / PNAS citation overlap: (see Lucas et al. 2023 and Springmann 2016) — both used as above to support large‑scale externality savings.

Systemiq (A Taste of Tomorrow), 2025 — 'The economic potential of alternative proteins' for Germany (high‑ambition scenario: up to €65 billion and up to 250,000 jobs by 2045). https://www.systemiq.earth/economic-potential-alternative-proteins/

Faunalytics (Wulderk), 2025 — 'The Economic Impacts Of A Plant‑Based Transition' (BW Research analysis; optimistic scenario for US: ~70,000 net jobs and ≈$200–224 billion added to GDP in a high‑adoption scenario). https://faunalytics.org/plant-based-economic-impacts/

ClimateWorks Foundation / GINA (Global Innovation Needs Assessment), 2023 — synthesis reporting that investments and shifts (including alternative proteins) could support up to ~83 million jobs and large economic value by 2050 (GINA/ClimateWorks summaries). https://www.climateworks.org/ginas-methane/

Green Alliance, 2023 — 'Appetite for change: why the UK should lead the emerging alternative proteins market' (UK scenario: up to £6.8bn and ~25,000 jobs by 2035). https://green-alliance.org.uk/publication/appetite-for-change-why-the-uk-should-lead-the-emerging-alternative-proteins-market/

Bryant Research (Bryant Research insight items, 2024/2025) — 'Climate‑Conscious & Cost‑Effective: A Case for Plant‑Based University Catering' (medium university ~£500k/yr savings) and 'The £2 billion NHS Windfall' (estimates). https://bryantresearch.co.uk/insight-items/

Office of Health Economics / medRxiv preprint (Henderson & Sampson), 2023 — model‑based estimates: England adopting plant‑based diets → NHS savings ≈£6.7bn/year (preprint funded by The Vegan Society; posted on medRxiv). https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.12.26.23300536v1

MDPI / Nutrients and VeChi Youth / German analyses (Hohoff et al. & other German studies; 2021–2022) — mixed findings: vegetarian diets sometimes cheapest; vegan diets can be cheaper or more expensive depending on menu composition. Example: Nutrients/VeChi Youth 2022 (children/adolescents) and 'Affordability of Different Isocaloric Healthy Diets in Germany' (Nutrients 2021, 13(9):3037) https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8472114/ and https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9573339/

Press coverage and secondary summaries used to cross‑check scenario framing (Reuters, GreenQueen, GFI summaries) — used only to verify how reports were framed in public discourse (e.g., Reuters summary of Systemiq and Faunalytics reporting).
